posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: We are planning on using a rev color sensor and wiring it into the MXP port.  Is there a best practice, or a good plug-in connector for the pins on the mxp?  I’d rather not use pwm housings like we have in the past - it always works out poorly.
We’re using a NavX anyway, and the pins on it have worked rather well for us in the past.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Both of those rules apply to hooking up actuators.  In this case all of the devices being discussed are sensors, so wiring direct to the port is fine (or building a custom board not listed in R713, assuming other rules are followed).  It is worth bringing attention to those rules for people looking at hooking up PWM motor controllers to the MXP, though!

reply_to_user.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Well, at this point I’m going with a 2x6 housing.  I’ll populate all the pins to keep it snug.  I just wish there was a more effective option other than an expansion board.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You could pair a 34-pin IDC ribbon cable with a 34-pin IDC ribbon cable breakout board like this one: 34-PIN Male Header Breakout Board

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I have a love hate relationship with ribbon cables in FRC.  Seems like no matter how many times I caution the members, they end up destroying them.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: The Rev More Board would let you use the same connector as the onboard I2C port.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I actually have 3 more boards and was considering using them, but the I2C on them is no different, just vertical pins with no locking feature.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked:
You can use all that free time we get during build season to make your own MXP board. This one is from 2015, before we used CAN much.

suggested_topics.title: R613, PDP Location
suggested_topics.excerpt: As long as it is safe, and you are able to flip your robot over for inspection you should be fine. It is only a requirement to be able to see during inspection.
